verses.text: Therefore, this is what the Holy One of Israel says: "Because you have rejected this message, relied on oppression and depended on deceit,

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:12
rsbNotes.text:
30:12 Therefore. Since they would not listen to God’s prophets, they will hear from Him in judgment.

word. That is, the word of God through Isaiah (vv. 8, 9).

oppression and perverseness. Jerusalem’s leaders were unprincipled, and their diplomacy resulted in oppression.

verses.text: this sin will become for you like a high wall, cracked and bulging, that collapses suddenly, in an instant.
It will break in pieces like pottery, shattered so mercilessly that among its pieces not a fragment will be found for taking coals from a hearth or scooping water out of a cistern."

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:13
rsbNotes.text: 30:13 iniquity. Their stubborn resistance to the Lord and dependence on Egypt will bring about their downfall.

verses.text: This is what the Sovereign LORD, the Holy One of Israel, says: "In repentance and rest is your salvation, in quietness and trust is your strength, but you would have none of it.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:15
rsbNotes.text:
30:15 Lord God. See note 25:7.

rest . . . quietness. The Lord can give His people what they searched for in Egypt.

be saved . . . strength. The Lord is the strength of His people and He will be victorious (12:2 note).

verses.text: You said, 'No, we will flee on horses.' Therefore you will flee! You said, 'We will ride off on swift horses.' Therefore your pursuers will be swift!

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:16
rsbNotes.text: 30:16 horses. They depended on military strength and stratagems (2:7 note; 31:1, 3).

verses.text: A thousand will flee at the threat of one; at the threat of five you will all flee away, till you are left like a flagstaff on a mountaintop, like a banner on a hill."

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:17
rsbNotes.text: 30:17 thousand . . . one. This is a reversal of God’s promise to give His people victory (Lev. 26:7, 8; Deut. 32:30; Josh. 23:10).

verses.text: Yet the LORD longs to be gracious to you; he rises to show you compassion. For the LORD is a God of justice. Blessed are all who wait for him!

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:18
rsbNotes.text: 30:18 justice. God upholds His kingdom in His patience (1:21 note).

verses.text: O people of Zion, who live in Jerusalem, you will weep no more. How gracious he will be when you cry for help! As soon as he hears, he will answer you.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:19
rsbNotes.text: 30:19 weep. See note 25:7, 8; cf. Rev. 7:17; 21:4.

verses.text: Although the Lord gives you the bread of adversity and the water of affliction, your teachers will be hidden no more; with your own eyes you will see them.
Whether you turn to the right or to the left, your ears will hear a voice behind you, saying, "This is the way; walk in it."

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:20
rsbNotes.text: 30:20 Teacher. For God’s instruction, see 28:11–13; 29:11, 12. After His judgment they will see His salvation (29:24).

verses.text: Then you will defile your idols overlaid with silver and your images covered with gold; you will throw them away like a menstrual cloth and say to them, "Away with you!"

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:22
rsbNotes.text:
30:22 On Isaiah’s polemic against idolatry, see 2:8.

defile. That is, desecrate (2 Kin. 23:4–8).

verses.text: He will also send you rain for the seed you sow in the ground, and the food that comes from the land will be rich and plentiful. In that day your cattle will graze in broad meadows.
The oxen and donkeys that work the soil will eat fodder and mash, spread out with fork and shovel.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:23
rsbNotes.text:
30:23 rain . . . bread. These blessings will come in response to the repentance apparent in the preceding verses (v. 20; cf. Deut. 28:11, 12).

In that day. See note 2:11.

verses.text: In the day of great slaughter, when the towers fall, streams of water will flow on every high mountain and every lofty hill.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:25
rsbNotes.text:
30:25 brooks. Isaiah uses exaggeration to proclaim God’s abundant blessings prepared for His children (cf. Joel 3:18; Amos 9:13).

day of the great slaughter. The day of the Lord (cf. 34:2, 6; Jer. 12:3; 19:6; 46:10; Zeph. 1:7, 8).

towers. Symbols of human pride (2:12–17).

verses.text: The moon will shine like the sun, and the sunlight will be seven times brighter, like the light of seven full days, when the LORD binds up the bruises of his people and heals the wounds he inflicted.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:26
rsbNotes.text:
30:26 sevenfold. Here the exaggerated figure indicates that God is with His people (2:5 note; 42:16; 60:19; Rev. 21:22, 23).

binds up . . . heals. God disciplines, but He remembers and heals the wounds of His people (19:22; 57:18; 61:1; Ps. 147:3; Jer. 3:22; 30:17; but cf. Is. 6:10).

verses.text: See, the Name of the LORD comes from afar, with burning anger and dense clouds of smoke; his lips are full of wrath, and his tongue is a consuming fire.
His breath is like a rushing torrent, rising up to the neck. He shakes the nations in the sieve of destruction; he places in the jaws of the peoples a bit that leads them astray.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:27
rsbNotes.text:
30:27 name of the Lord. The covenant name represents God (12:2 note; cf. Ex. 3:14).

lips . . . tongue. Isaiah uses the resources of poetry to depict the angry power of God.

verses.text: And you will sing as on the night you celebrate a holy festival; your hearts will rejoice as when people go up with flutes to the mountain of the LORD, to the Rock of Israel.
The LORD will cause men to hear his majestic voice and will make them see his arm coming down with raging anger and consuming fire, with cloudburst, thunderstorm and hail.
The voice of the LORD will shatter Assyria; with his scepter he will strike them down.
Every stroke the LORD lays on them with his punishing rod will be to the music of tambourines and harps, as he fights them in battle with the blows of his arm.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:29
rsbNotes.text:
30:29 song . . . flute. This celebration is like that of a pilgrimage feast.

mountain. See note 2:2.

verses.text: Topheth has long been prepared; it has been made ready for the king. Its fire pit has been made deep and wide, with an abundance of fire and wood; the breath of the LORD, like a stream of burning sulfur, sets it ablaze.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:33
rsbNotes.text: 30:33 burning place. In Hebrew “Topheth.” Topheth was a pit on the south side of Jerusalem where children had been sacrificed and a continual fire burned to consume the refuse that was thrown there (57:5; 2 Kin. 23:10; Jer. 7:31, 32; 19:6, 11–13).

verses.text: Woe to those who go down to Egypt for help, who rely on horses, who trust in the multitude of their chariots and in the great strength of their horsemen, but do not look to the Holy One of Israel, or seek help from the LORD.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 31:1
rsbNotes.text:
31:1 Egypt . . . horsemen. Judah thought they could be delivered by Egyptian horses and chariots (30:2).

look to. One way of seeking the Lord is to consult His prophets (29:9, 10; 30:1).

the Holy One of Israel. See note 1:4.

verses.text: Yet he too is wise and can bring disaster; he does not take back his words. He will rise up against the house of the wicked, against those who help evildoers.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 31:2
rsbNotes.text:
31:2 he is wise. This prophetic sarcasm ridicules the royal counselors.

disaster. He is sovereign in judgment (45:7).

verses.text: But the Egyptians are men and not God; their horses are flesh and not spirit. When the LORD stretches out his hand, he who helps will stumble, he who is helped will fall; both will perish together.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 31:3
rsbNotes.text: 31:3 Egyptians . . . not spirit. This model of poetic parallelism contrasts flesh and spirit, creature and Creator (2:22; Ps. 56:4; John 4:24).

verses.text: This is what the LORD says to me: "As a lion growls, a great lion over his prey- and though a whole band of shepherds is called together against him, he is not frightened by their shouts or disturbed by their clamor- so the LORD Almighty will come down to do battle on Mount Zion and on its heights.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 31:4
rsbNotes.text: 31:4 lion . . . not terrified. The Lord is as determined as a lion. Assyrian kings likened themselves to lions, proverbial for their strength and ferocity.

verses.text: Like birds hovering overhead, the LORD Almighty will shield Jerusalem; he will shield it and deliver it, he will 'pass over' it and will rescue it."
Return to him you have so greatly revolted against, O Israelites.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 31:5
rsbNotes.text: 31:5 protect Jerusalem. The Lord cares for His people like a mother bird (Ex. 19:4; Deut. 32:11, 12).

verses.text: For in that day every one of you will reject the idols of silver and gold your sinful hands have made.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 31:7
rsbNotes.text:
31:7 in that day. See note 2:11.

idols . . . hands. On Isaiah’s polemic against idolatry, see 2:8.

verses.text: "Assyria will fall by a sword that is not of man; a sword, not of mortals, will devour them. They will flee before the sword and their young men will be put to forced labor.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 31:8
rsbNotes.text: 31:8 shall fall. Assyria will come to an end by God’s hand and at His time, not by human stratagems (37:36).

verses.text: Their stronghold will fall because of terror; at sight of the battle standard their commanders will panic," declares the LORD, whose fire is in Zion, whose furnace is in Jerusalem.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 31:9
rsbNotes.text:
31:9 rock. Assyria will be looking for a place to hide (Rev. 6:16).

fire . . . furnace. See 4:5 note; 10:17; 30:27, 30, 33.

verses.text: See, a king will reign in righteousness and rulers will rule with justice.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 32:1–3
rsbNotes.text: 32:1–3 The peace and harmony of godly leadership.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 32:1
rsbNotes.text: 32:1 king . . . princes. This means the Messiah (9:1–7; 11:1–9) and godly leaders (1:26; 1 Pet. 5:2).

verses.text: Each man will be like a shelter from the wind and a refuge from the storm, like streams of water in the desert and the shadow of a great rock in a thirsty land.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 32:2
rsbNotes.text: 32:2 shelter . . . great rock. The protective role of the king and his cohorts results from their dependence on the Lord (4:6 note); in contrast to any reliance on Egypt (30:1, 2, 12; 31:1, 3).

verses.text: Then the eyes of those who see will no longer be closed, and the ears of those who hear will listen.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 32:3
rsbNotes.text: 32:3 eyes . . . ears. This is in contrast to 6:9, 10; 29:9, 10; 30:1, 2; 31:1. See note 29:18.

verses.text: The mind of the rash will know and understand, and the stammering tongue will be fluent and clear.
No longer will the fool be called noble nor the scoundrel be highly respected.
For the fool speaks folly, his mind is busy with evil: He practices ungodliness and spreads error concerning the LORD; the hungry he leaves empty and from the thirsty he withholds water.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 32:4
rsbNotes.text: 32:4 heart . . . tongue. This is all in fulfillment of 29:24.

verses.text: The scoundrel's methods are wicked, he makes up evil schemes to destroy the poor with lies, even when the plea of the needy is just.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 32:7
rsbNotes.text: 32:7 poor . . . needy. See Ps. 9:18 note.

verses.text: But the noble man makes noble plans, and by noble deeds he stands.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 32:8
rsbNotes.text: 32:8 he who is noble. He stands in contrast to the fool, who is willing to oppress the needy (vv. 5–7).

verses.text: You women who are so complacent, rise up and listen to me; you daughters who feel secure, hear what I have to say!

rsbNotes.title: Isa 32:9
rsbNotes.text:
32:9 women . . . at ease. The people were confident of succeeding in their schemes (vv. 5–7; cf. 3:16–24; Amos 6:1; Zech. 1:15).

complacent. This is the same word rendered “trust” in v. 17 and “secure” in v. 18. The false security based on confidence in Egypt contrasts with the true security based on trust in God.

verses.text: In little more than a year you who feel secure will tremble; the grape harvest will fail, and the harvest of fruit will not come.
Tremble, you complacent women; shudder, you daughters who feel secure! Strip off your clothes, put sackcloth around your waists.
Beat your breasts for the pleasant fields, for the fruitful vines

rsbNotes.title: Isa 32:10
rsbNotes.text: 32:10 grape harvest . . . fruit harvest. Poor harvest is an indication of God’s judgment.

verses.text: and for the land of my people, a land overgrown with thorns and briers- yes, mourn for all houses of merriment and for this city of revelry.
The fortress will be abandoned, the noisy city deserted; citadel and watchtower will become a wasteland forever, the delight of donkeys, a pasture for flocks,

rsbNotes.title: Isa 32:13
rsbNotes.text:
32:13 soil . . . city. Everything will become a wasteland (cf. 5:5, 6; 16:8–10; 24:7–13; 34:13–15).

exultant city. See notes 22:2, 13.

verses.text: till the Spirit is poured upon us from on high, and the desert becomes a fertile field, and the fertile field seems like a forest.
Justice will dwell in the desert and righteousness live in the fertile field.
The fruit of righteousness will be peace; the effect of righteousness will be quietness and confidence forever.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 32:15
rsbNotes.text:
32:15 Spirit. The Holy Spirit transforms everything according to God’s order. He is the Spirit of restoration. See 11:2; 28:6; 42:1; 61:1; Ezek. 36:27; Joel 2:28, 29.

from on high. The Spirit is above all earthly powers (Ps. 93:4; Luke 24:49; Eph. 4:8).

wilderness . . . forest. See note 29:17.

verses.text: My people will live in peaceful dwelling places, in secure homes, in undisturbed places of rest.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 32:18
rsbNotes.text: 32:18 My people. See note 40:1.

verses.text: Though hail flattens the forest and the city is leveled completely,
how blessed you will be, sowing your seed by every stream, and letting your cattle and donkeys range free.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 32:19
rsbNotes.text: 32:19 hail. See note 28:2.

verses.text: Woe to you, O destroyer, you who have not been destroyed! Woe to you, O traitor, you who have not been betrayed! When you stop destroying, you will be destroyed; when you stop betraying, you will be betrayed.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33
rsbNotes.text: 33:1–24 This sixth and final oracle of woe in chs. 28–33 is against Assyria. By focusing on Assyria’s defeat and Judah’s exaltation, the Lord, the King of Judah, is exalted.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:1
rsbNotes.text: 33:1 destroyer . . . betrayed. Though Assyria is the reference in the historical context (cf. 10:5, 12, 24; 14:25; 30:31; 31:8; 2 Kin. 18:13–16; 19:32–37), it represents any power opposed to God.

verses.text: O LORD, be gracious to us; we long for you. Be our strength every morning, our salvation in time of distress.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:2
rsbNotes.text: 33:2 This verse begins a prayer for mercy during the hour of judgment.

verses.text: At the thunder of your voice, the peoples flee; when you rise up, the nations scatter.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:3
rsbNotes.text: 33:3 scattered. See Num. 10:35.

verses.text: Your plunder, O nations, is harvested as by young locusts; like a swarm of locusts men pounce on it.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:4
rsbNotes.text: 33:4 your spoil. The spoils go to the Lord, victor over the nations (23:18).

verses.text: The LORD is exalted, for he dwells on high; he will fill Zion with justice and righteousness.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:5
rsbNotes.text: 33:5 dwells on high. See note 32:15.

verses.text: He will be the sure foundation for your times, a rich store of salvation and wisdom and knowledge; the fear of the LORD is the key to this treasure.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:6
rsbNotes.text:
33:6 salvation. See note 12:2.

Zion’s treasure. See text note. Probably the meaning is that the best gift a person can receive from God is the pure faith that is formed in response to the revelation of God’s grace (Ps. 130:4; Prov. 9:10; Luke 5:10).

verses.text: Look, their brave men cry aloud in the streets; the envoys of peace weep bitterly.
The highways are deserted, no travelers are on the roads. The treaty is broken, its witnesses are despised, no one is respected.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:7–12
rsbNotes.text: 33:7–12 With all Judah’s false hopes gone (vv. 7–9), the Lord acts to destroy Assyria.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:7
rsbNotes.text:
33:7 heroes. Perhaps this sarcasm is directed at the three officials who conversed with Assyria (36:3, 22).

cry . . . weep. Human ploys have failed. International trade, diplomacy, and military expeditions have come to an end. The Assyrians accepted gifts and tribute from Judah but treacherously continued their siege.

verses.text: The land mourns and wastes away, Lebanon is ashamed and withers; Sharon is like the Arabah, and Bashan and Carmel drop their leaves.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:9
rsbNotes.text: 33:9 land . . . Carmel. Areas famous for their fertility have become like deserts (2:13; 29:17; 32:13 and notes). For the transformation, see 35:1, 2.
